summary: Build an Indian bank statement PDF to Excel converter.
architectural_notes: Add explicit bank template dropdown entries (e.g., HDFC) that switch parsing heuristics and column mappings; include a reference mapping/table for HDFC layouts.
known_issues: Some PDFs fail to convert when the transaction table cannot be reliably detected (e.g., scanned/image PDFs or irregular layouts such as certain HDFC statements).

existing_features.title: Create a single-page PDF-to-Excel converter UI that lets the user upload an Indian bank statement PDF, extracts the transaction table, previews the parsed rows, and exports the result as an .xlsx file.

Implement client-side PDF text/table extraction that works without sending the PDF to the backend, including a robust fallback flow for imperfect PDFs (scanned PDFs, irregular formatting) by allowing the user to adjust parsing settings and re-run extraction.

Add support for multiple Indian bank statement layouts by introducing a pluggable 'bank template' selection (e.g., Auto-detect, SBI, HDFC, ICICI, Axis, Kotak, Yes Bank, PNB), where each template defines parsing heuristics and column mapping.
Provide data cleanup tools in the preview step: column mapping, row editing, removing non-transaction rows, and basic normalization (date normalization and numeric parsing for debit/credit/balance).
Add a consistent, distinct visual theme for the app (colors, typography, spacing, and components) suitable for a finance utility tool; avoid blue/purple as primary colors.

Add basic privacy messaging and local-processing reassurance in the UI, stating that PDFs are processed locally in the browser and are not uploaded (unless the user explicitly enables any future save/share feature).
Render newly generated static image assets (logo and a lightweight hero/empty-state illustration) from frontend/public/assets/generated and use them in the app shell (header) and upload/empty state.

Add a short, user-facing guidance section on the main PDF-to-Excel page that explains (1) the 3-step process (Upload → Review → Export) and (2) why the app generates an Excel (.xlsx) file after parsing a bank-statement PDF. The guidance must be in English and should be visible from the Upload step without requiring a PDF to be selected.

Add a new optional transaction field for HDFC statements: a “Reference” value (also commonly labeled as Ref No, Reference No, UTR, or Chq/Ref No) so extracted transactions can store and display this value.
Update the Review step transactions table UI to include a “Reference” column that is visible and editable (inline edit) alongside Date, Description, Debit, Credit, and Balance.
Include the “Reference” column in the exported Excel (.xlsx) output, and ensure it exports the currently edited values from the Review table.

Enhance the HDFC bank template configuration and extraction diagnostics to recognize a Reference column label (e.g., “Reference”, “Ref No”, “Reference No”, “UTR”, “Chq/Ref No”) and report it in detected columns when present.

new_feature_requests.summary: Create a converter tool that parses Indian bank statement PDFs and exports the data to an Excel file.
Add an HDFC Bank option to the bank-template dropdown and include HDFC-specific parsing rules plus a 'Reference' table/column mapping to improve extraction.
